Nelson Bighetti is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.

 Caio talked about grad courses he is going to take. Those are algorihtms, competitive programming, quantitative methods for computer science, and finally a two weeks research guidance course.  Audio  Objectives
 Follow-up what each member has been self-studying,and exchanging feedbacks.  Summary
 Caio’s master thesis is going to use logic technique and rigour. That’s why he is interested in learning discrete math and logic through Rosen’s book. Master is probably going to be about program verification and hardware algorithms like registers allocation problem. Mostafa, besides rosen’s book, recommends book of proof and Applied Logic for Computer Scientists. Lucas is already familiar with discrete math and logic; What is missing from him is the capability of applying them in algorithms context. Currently he is training on graph and greedy algorithms through Introduction to Algorithms: A Creative Approach Lucas asked Mostafa about theoretical CS, where he wishes to know whether reductions and NP-completeness proofs are accessble with minimal background in algorithms. Lucas also noted Bondy and Murty’s graph theory book contains a chapter about complexity theory even though the book is not about algorithms. He wondered whether only combinatorics are sufficient to achieve a progress. Mostafa confirms theoretical CS is can be approached mainly through combinatorics; Generally, It can approached by algorithms or logic as well. Lucas praised erik’s super collaboration. He loves also to tackle open problems in graph theory, while they are not related to his main research field, which is computational biology. He talked about genome assembly problem, which is heavily based on graph theory, particularly hamiltonian paths. Mostafa showed MAA magazines, illustrating its goal for exposing ideas to a wider audience, captivating their interest in a way that invokes a discussion. The meeting has ended-up where everyone achnowledged the value of exchanging perspectives. It is hoped members share more technical ideas after having achieved a good technical progress.  Quotes

 Everyone expressed struggling with the course, and nearly all members couldn’t solve the exercises.  Quotes
 mostafa: I am encouraged by everyone’s willingness to express her/his struggle, and to persistently learn from mistakes and improve.   Weekly Meeting (12/02/2022) Links
 Audio  Objectives
 Technical discussion, Lectures and Assignment 1. Casual discussion, whether the course was too difficult. Casual discussion, Generally related to the course. Social, Meeting new members.  Summary
 ben introduces himself: graduated from math major, transitioned to software industry and has been working for 2 years. intersted now in theoretical computer science. caio introduces himself: fresh CS alumni; currently pursuing a master in compilers; motivated to study algorithms for code optimization. lucper and caio are friends and had an internships together. most members did not solve assignment 1 but they are planning for it the next week end. for most members, this course is the first time they see proofs within the context of algorithms. ben initiates a discussion, simple algorithm but tricky proof  mostafa addressed understanding a solution, and being able to creatively come up with a new, are totally two different skills. lucper addresses that happens very commonly in combinatorics, A problem easily understood but very trikcy to solve it.   ben asks whether it is a pattern for greedy algorithms to be solved by induction  mostafa answers when an algorithm is formulated recursively or in terms of smaller instances of the same problem, Then induction is a very likely approach. caio agrees what mostafa as he had a similar advice from his professor. lucper pointes to algorithm design book by Kleinberg and Tardos for an alternative proof by contradiction   mostafa initaties a discussion, school systems are not the best environment for training on creatively coming up with novel ideas. mostafa initaites a discussion, thinking of simpler problems or different versions as a problem solving strategy.  ben expresses this is his main strategy. caio mentions a quote from how to prove it by George Polya. lucper agrees.   mostafa ends up the with posing a question: If progressing slowly by thinking of related problems is our sole approach for progress, Is it possible to achieve breakthroughs or unexpected leaps?  Quotes
 caio: if you cannot solve a problem, try to think of an easier version for it.   First Meeting (05/02/2022) Links
